body: @rajinisivaram, thanks for the PR. It would also be really good to have a system test that actually failed if hostname verification failed.
@ijuma Yes, agree. Will add tests to the PR.
@dguy @guozhangwang could you have a look? Thanks.
I have applied the PR on the trunk branch and tested it. Apparently the bug is solved.
LGTM.
Yeah, that would be great. Thanks!

It looks like the current PR implementation isn't right.

Say the replica requests a fetch starting from offset x. It's possible that the record at x is larger than the broker's current max message size for the __consumer_offsets topic. This can happen if record x was appended to the log before the topic's max message size config was reduced on the leader broker. This means taking the max between the requested fetch size and the broker's __consumer_offsets topic configured max message size won't be enough to consume record x.
hey @guozhangwang -- the overhead of the String.replace() + HashSet construction was approx 7% of the overall run time IIRC.

Created the JIRA here, sorry for the delay.

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3811
Thanks @gfodor Let me follow-up on the above points with a PR, and would be great if you can help trying out the optimization patch once it is out.
Keep in mind that `String.replace(String)` allocates a `Pattern` and compiles it on the fly. `String.replace(char)` is a lot more efficient.
Good to learn, thanks @ijuma :)
Good find, thanks @enothereska !!

Ok @ijuma @guozhangwang @andresgomezfrr I'm splitting this JIRA into two and fixing the issue where you use **different** state dirs on the same machine. I'll hold off to the lock fix (**same** state dir) as part of KAFKA-3812. This is because we are rethinking state store names and it is premature to put in a fix before that is done.

LGTM overall, maybe we can add one comment in line 341 of `ProcessStateManager` that "flushing and closing the store just in case they are not explicitly done by processor node". And also update the comment of `close` in `StateStore` that this function should be idempotent?

Some context: in the DSL we intentionally do not close stores in `close` and rely on the state manger to close them in the end just to be sure the whole topology is "cleaned up" before we start closing the store; but we cannot control users to explicitly close them. So we need to make this function call idempotent.
@enothereska, can you update the PR title since the locked resource change is no longer included
Done @guozhangwang

I think we still cannot call `logUnused` at the end because the configs may be used later when tasks / state managers are created, and users may want to pass extra config values that will only be used in `ProcessorContext`, plus we construct the produce / consumer configs by copying the property value.
OK, fair enough.
@ijuma Mind taking another look?
@jklukas @enothereska @mjsax @dguy for reviews.
Hi @gfodor , could you check if #1465 handles this issue or not?

The updated state machine diagram looks reasonable to me, and I will let @onurkaraman to take another check on it. One general comment about naming of `removeGroup` and `removeGroupForPartition`, and `onGroupLoaded`, `onGroupUnloaded`, could we differentiate them better by name the ones, for example: `deleteGroup`, `evictGroupsFromCacheForPartition`, and `onGroupLoadedToCache` `onGroupEvictedFromCache`. And also add some comments on when they could be triggered?

@guozhangwang 
Changes made per comments, added an integration test demonstrating picking up a matching topic that is added after the streams instance has started. Also updated the Metadata object, if a matching topic is deleted while KStreams is running a NullPointerException is thrown during the rebalance. 

I need some guidance for a counter test - removing a matching topic once a KStreams program has started.  Very tough to get to the subscription updates without resorting to some messy reflection work.

EDIT: To be more clear, I'm looking for another way to prove the regex subscriptions are correct after a rebalance, the case of adding a topic was easier, just confirm a message recieved.   Would this be a test for the StreamsPartitionAssignor?

This pull request supersedes #626. 

I opened a new pull request in order to reduce confusion based on old/outdated discussion. 
All reviews from that pull request were taken into consideration here. 
Thank you to @guozhangwang, @gwenshap, @ijuma, @hachikuji, and @junrao  for reviews on that PR.

For the latest discussion on this KIP change please see the Kafka dev. mailing list.
@ijuma Addressed comments.
Addressed comments.
LGTM +1

Review by @gfodor @ijuma @junrao @aartigupta. Changes include:
1. Reduce number of `time.millisecond` calls in run-loop.
2. Not recording if polling with zero only.
3. Use `time.milliseconds` instead of `time.nanoseconds` for state metrics recording, and also fixed a bug with the recording.

@gfodor Could you apply this patch and see if it reduced CPU overhead? One note is that if your traffic is very small and consumer is already at the log tail throughout your test, it will cause the polling / processing to be called with less batched data and hence further increased overhead.
Thanks @jklukas , merged to trunk and 0.10.0.

btw I think I have seen this test case stalled once before already:

```

kafka.integration.SaslSslTopicMetadataTest > testIsrAfterBrokerShutDownAndJoinsBack STARTED
Build timed out (after 120 minutes). Marking the build as failed.
```

Maybe we could create a JIRA for it @ijuma ?
This should be ready for another look, @guozhangwang and @ijuma
Made a pass over the PR, looks great ! I especially am very glad to see all the added tests. Left some comments inline.

@bbejeck I think one way to validate that added / removed topics are handled is to check the removed / created tasks instead of checking the processed messages; i.e. if a new topic is added, the new tasks corresponding to this new topic should be created in the rebalance callback (i.e. `addStreamTasks`), and similarly for deleted topics, we should see that first all tasks are removed, and they are re-created in the rebalance again but without the deleted topic partitions assigned any more.

We can override the `removeStreamTasks` and `createStreamTask` in StreamThread to do this validation. And let me know if you still cannot observe the rebalance happening after topics deleted.
An unrelated test failed. Closing to try the PR again.
Reopening PR
LGTM
LGTM, thanks for the cleanup!
LGTM, thanks!

@deragon Left a few minor comments that should be easy to clean up. I'm open to merging this, but I'll want to also trigger a full system test run before doing so. We've recently run into quite a few compatibility issues with changes to the shell scripts and they don't have any testing besides the system tests, so we're treading carefully with any new changes. Once we've got a completed patch in place I'd like to validate on my own Windows VM, and the system tests should hopefully give good coverage on Linux.

Also, can you fix up the PR title to match the naming suggested in the [contribution guidelines](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Contributing+Code+Changes#ContributingCodeChanges-PullRequest).

I started a system test build against the current patch [here](https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/467/). We should follow up on the final patch, but since the comments I had were minor, I figure it's worth testing against the current version to catch any issues asap.
Left a few minor comment, the rest LGTM. Feel free to merge after fixing them.

Hey @guozhangwang unfortunately, it's no longer easy for me to profile this job under the same conditions as previously. We've since moved things around so filtering of messages happens upstream so almost all the messages previously hitting the job (and subsequently discarded) no longer even get there.

Ran org.apache.kafka.streams.perf.SimpleBenchmark with the following configuration (i.e. without state store backed streams and simple print statements indicating which part of the benchmark is being run) ``` System.out.println("producer"); benchmark.produce(); System.out.println("consumer "); benchmark.consume(); System.out.println("simple stream performance source->process"); // simple stream performance source->process benchmark.processStream(); System.out.println("simple stream performance source->sink"); // simple stream performance source->sink benchmark.processStreamWithSink(); // simple stream performance source->store ``` // benchmark.processStreamWithStateStore(); then attached a yourkit profiler and saw the following differences (see attached screenshots) without any changes to the code and using CPU Sampling in yourkit saw 61% cpu contention with the per node metrics and using CPU sampling in yourkit, saw 70% cpu contention, without any changes org.apache.kafka.streams.perf.SimpleBenchmark producer Producer Performance [MB/sec write]: 8.853212193170378 consumer [YourKit Java Profiler 2016.02-b38] Log file: /Users/aartikumargupta/.yjp/log/SimpleBenchmark-1754.log Consumer Performance [MB/sec read]: 4.596191726854892 simple stream performance source->process Streams Performance [MB/sec read]: 14.361679855964493 simple stream performance source->sink Streams Performance [MB/sec read+write]: 4.535097423059803 with node metrics Producer Performance [MB/sec write]: 5.035256582778346 consumer [YourKit Java Profiler 2016.02-b38] Log file: /Users/aartikumargupta/.yjp/log/SimpleBenchmark-1549.log Consumer Performance [MB/sec read]: 2.751484036579496 simple stream performance source->process Streams Performance [MB/sec read]: 8.014018691588785 simple stream performance source->sink Streams Performance [MB/sec read+write]: 6.562667414985077 Ran this multiple times and the results varied between 63%(no changes) and 72%(with per node metrics) The difference seems to be around the point at which yourkit profiler is attached That said, not sure if this is a valid load simulating scenario @guozhangwang mentions in https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1490 that > > if your traffic is very small and consumer is already at the log tail throughout your test, it will cause the polling / processing to be called with less batched data and hence further increased overhead. @guozhangwang Is the simpleBenchmark a good scenario to be profiling ? If not any suggestions on another scenario, maybe we can add (check in) such a scenario under examples, which can be used for all similar future profiling exercises Still working on the unit tests for per node metrics.
Nice addition to tests!

LGTM

My concern is that configuring security is challenging enough as it is. Configuring authorization incorrectly is very common and harder to diagnose than a topic that hasn't been created (even the latter sometimes causes people to be confused and waste time).

Replacing an exception with indefinite blocking is making the user experience during development even worse than it is at the moment (which is already suboptimal in a number of situations). Ideally, we would be moving in the other direction.

If we decide to do this, then at the very least, we need to think about how users will diagnose the problem and update the authorization documentation with the information.
Ok, LGTM
LGTM
LGTM

Thanks for the PR. Thoughts @fpj?

@ijuma At the very least, we can change the consumer/producer log messages to warn the user that the topic might not exist or they might not have access to it. I agree this is less than ideal, but I don't see an alternative other than what I suggested above (changing how the client handles unknown topics). That is, unless we think this patch is not worth having at all. I was a little torn on this initially, but it does seem better to avoid leaking topic information.
@hachikuji The log warning you have suggested seems like our best bet at the moment.
I fixed the style issue.
@ewencp Thanks for the comment, add some unit test to address the case that `task.commitRecord` can throw exception.

This mostly looks good w/ one comment re: where we allocate payloads.

The other question I have is whether we're treating these tools as public API. This changes the output format (thread IDs in windowed output) and some previously valid command line flag combos (any compression enabled since `--value-bound` didn't previously exist and is now defaulting to 0, which the tool now considers an invalid combo).

Also, system tests use ProducerPerformance and parse its output. They may not be affected since they might only need the final reported line, but we should probably run tests that might be affected before merging.
LGTM

@ewencp Thanks for the suggestion. My original thought was to test more scenarios. I do agree with you that we should avoid transient failures whenever possible. I updated the PR to make the test deterministic.
